item.title: Qudit Measurement on IBM Quantum Hardware
item.description:
Sweep of readout-drive frequency for a ququart state, see Fig. X.X(a).

Measurement of ququart states on ibm_lagos Q4 (July 7, 2023). Drive-frequency-dependent and qudit-state-dependent resonator amplitudes, the experimental equivalent of Fig. X.X(a). The colored dots are the measurement results of all N = 2000 shots for each prepared Fock state for the drive frequency ωd = ω0 + Δωd with ω0/2π = 7.2463 GHz. The black crosses mark the centers of their Gaussian fits. The colored curves (with white shadows) correspond to the centers of Gaussian fits to the Fock states | j ⟩.

item.title: Swarmalators
item.description:
Examples of several states of the swarmalator phase diagram, see Fig. X.X.
The video has two time scales t∈[0,150] and t∈[150,1000].

Classes of steady states of N=100 swarmalators after a duration of t=1000. The top row shows the steady states in 2D position space where the color corresponds to ϕj - Ψ, i.e., the phase of each swarmalator subtracted by the complex phase of the order parameter W defined in Eq. (X.X). The order parameter R is the Kuramoto model order parameter defined in Eq. (X.X). The second row shows the correlation between the phase ϕj - Ψ of the swarmalators and their azimuthal angle φj. (a) Static Asynch (StA) for (K,J)=(-0.8,0.2). (b) Active Phase Wave (ActPW) for (K,J)=(-0.8,1). (c) Splintered Phase Wave (SpPW) for (K,J)=(-0.1,1). (d) Static Phase Wave (StPW) for (K,J)=(0,1). (e) Static Synch (StS) for (K,J)=(0.1,0.2). For small |W|, Ψ is fluctuating and leads to the fluctuation of the color even if ϕj is stable.

item.title: Two Classical Nonreciprocally Coupled Oscillators
item.description:
Mean-field equations of two nonreciprocally coupled oscillators, see Fig. X.X.

Two oscillators with external drive ΩA = 0.5ɣAg described by Eqs. (X.X) and (X.X). (a) Phase diagram where each color denotes a different phase. White pixels were not assigned any phase. The gray line denotes g̃ = gAB. (b) Spectrum 𝒮AA(ωA) for g̃ = 0.7ɣAd (location of upper symbols in (a)). The dashed white curves indicate ω± and 2ω± defined in Eq. (X.X). Panels (c) to (e) show the time evolutions of one phase each corresponding to the symbol next to the panel label. The values of gAB and g̃ equal the coordinates of the respective symbol in (a). (c) Phase locking to ϕA = ϕB = -π/2. (d) Wobble motion: varying amplitudes and oscillating phases around ϕAB ≈ ±π/2. (e) Partial traveling-wave states: constantly increasing ϕA, oscillating ϕB around -π/2. The yellow phase (top left) corresponds to phase locking to ϕAB = π, similar to Fig. X(c), where for g̃>gAB (g̃<gAB) ϕA = -π/2 (ϕA = π/2). The darker orange phase (center right) hosts modulated traveling-wave states, similar to Fig. X(d). A list of rules and thresholds for each class of steady states is given in.

item.title: Three Classical Nonreciprocally Coupled Oscillators
item.description:
Mean-field equations of three nonreciprocally coupled oscillators, see Fig. X.X.

Open chain of three oscillators described by Eq. (X.X). (a) Phase diagram where each color denotes a different phase. White pixels were not assigned any phase. Panels (b) to (g) show the time evolutions of one phase each corresponding to the symbol next to the panel label. The values of g– and g̃ equal the coordinates of the respective symbol in (a). (b) Phase locking to Δϕj = ϕj - ϕj+1 = π. (c) Wobble motion: varying amplitudes and oscillating phases around Δϕj ≈ π. (d) Both wobble motion (c) and traveling-wave states (f) exist. (e) Modulated traveling-wave states: varying amplitudes and oscillating phases around Δϕj ≈ ±2π/3. (f) Traveling-wave states: constantly increasing phases with fixed Δϕj ≈ ±2π/3. (g) Phase locking to Δϕj = 0. A list of rules and thresholds for each class of steady states is given in Sec. X.

item.title: Twin Limit Cycle Realized With Trapped Ions
item.description:
Sideband cooling and heating on different ion transitions, see Fig. X.X.
The video has two time scales t∈[0,1001] and t∈[1001,10000].

Preliminary data showing that a multi-limit-cycle oscillator can be realized by the nonlinear phonon-ion interaction described in Eq. (X.X). The parameters are sBSB = -sRSB = 1, Ω0BSB = Ω0RSB = 0.1κ, ηBSB = 0.8, and ηRSB = 0.9. (a) Wigner function and marginals of the final state of a time evolution of duration κt = 1000 starting from a coherent state |α=2 ⟩. (b) Populations ρn,n of the final state. The curves correspond to the heating ΩBSBn,n+1 and cooling ΩRSBn,n-1 sidebands, see Eq. (X.X). Populations of Fock numbers n≥19 are smaller than 10-4.
